summary: the spike (S) protein, known as S1, is responsible for attachment to host cells. the C-terminal part mediates virus fusion to host cells postattachment. the protein comprises four individually folded domains, designated S1A through S1D (2, 3) the localization of 2,3-sialic acids in the respiratory tract of both humans and dromedary camels has been mapped using lectin histochemistry (5). it is important to note that MERS-CoV S1A preferentially binds to short, sulfated, 2,3-linked monosialosaccharides and long, branched, di- and triantenary 2,3-linked sialic acids. these glycotopes were previously identified by glycan array analysis using nanoparticles displaying multivalent MERS-CoV S1A (5). using these nanoparticles, we developed a histochemistry-based technique to map these glycotopes in the tissues of different susceptible species. np-S1A binds specifically to the nasal epithelium of dromedary camels. these glycotopes are expressed in clusters of ciliated and goblet cells in the nasal epithelium in a random multifocal pattern. np-S1A binding is inhibited by prior neuraminidase treatment of these tissues. blet cells (arrows) are negative, unlike nasal ciliated columnar epithelial cells. np-S1A binding is abrogated by a nanobody against the S1A domain. the control nanobody does not bind to S1, S1A, and S1B. the control nanobody (29) was negative in all three ELISAs. each of the anti-S1A and anti-S1B nanobodies reacted specifically to its domain and to S1 in a dose-dependent manner. the identified S1A nanobody inhibited np-S1A binding to nasal epithelial cells, whereas the S1B-reactive nanobody did not. using lectin histochemistry revealed that the nasal epithelium of pigs does not express these sialic acids. unlike dromedary camels, both species do not express these glycotopes. the absence of these glycotopes in the nasal epithelium of rabbits further supports the fine specificity of A domain binding. MERS-CoV preferentially binds 2,3-linked sialic acids via its S1A domain and uses these sialic acids as an attachment factor. previous studies have shown that MERS-CoV-inoculated pigs and rabbits shed less infectious virus than did dromedary camels (6, 7, 10, 11, 27) MERS-CoV has been reported to use host cell proteases to mediate fusion to host cells (54–56) the virus has been shown to be sensitive to type I interferon, an essential host innate immune cytokine (5, 54–58) absence of these proteases and presence of an inhibiting host innate immune response could effectively limit MERS-CoV replication and transmission. 2,3-sialic acid glycotopes recognized by MERS-CoV S1A vary. these glycotopes and DPP4 are expressed in the nasal ciliated epithelial cells of dromedary camels,
